intro: Myriophyllum magdalenense, commonly known as the Magdalen watermilfoil, is a submerged aquatic plant native to freshwater ecosystems in North America. It belongs to the family Halothalaceae and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves that resemble those of watermilfoil. The plant typically grows in shallow, slow-moving waters and is often found in lakes and ponds. Its small, white flowers are usually borne in clusters and bloom in early summer. Myriophyllum magdalenense plays an important role in aquatic habitats by providing shelter for fish and invertebrates.
